OOPs!!

i had just described the dragon tsuba over the phone to my friend.

when he saw the pictures he identified it just has had Jim Gilbert

sorry guys. i will be morecare next time.

messages.subject: Re: Quest about Tsubas
messages.msgSnippet: ... wrote: I asked a friend who has the Dragon tsuba.  he states that it is in the Higa [spelling] style, they are Water Dragons;  it was cast in soft metal.
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:

I asked a friend who has the Dragon tsuba. he states that it is in
the Higa [spelling] style, they are Water Dragons; it was cast in
soft metal. yeah, mid - late shinshinto. always mumei. and more
likely was made for a ko-wakizashi not a tanto. too big for tanto.

doug e.


> Patrik,
> The undecorated mokko-shaped one is the older of the two. Given
the style of the plate and shape and the angle of the kozuka ana (the
oval opening) it may be as old as the late Muromachi to Momoyama
period (late 16th C). Given the style of raised rim, it would
probably be designated as a Katchushi (armor maker's) tsuba, although
that is more a convenient term than a literal truth. It's a nicely
proportioned and apparently well made guard, although simple. It
looks like there is black lacquer on a lot of the surface.
>
> The style of the dragon on the other tsuba is typical for Echizen
Kinai work from the mid to late Edo period. It's often seen in
larger tsuba, but less common in tanto guards. Given the soft detail
and the look of the seppa dai (the central flat oval) it might be
cast. I can't tell for sure from the photos.
>
> What does the rest of the mounting with the older guard look like?
>
> Jim
>
>
>

something
> about the tsubas that were mounted on them, se pics under photos
> Tsubas2.jpg , would be nice to now age or something on them
>
> Best Regards
>
> Patrik

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Quest about Tsubas
messages.msgSnippet: Patrik, The undecorated mokko-shaped one is the older of the two.  Given the style of the plate and shape and the angle of the kozuka ana (the oval opening) it
messages.messageBody:
Patrik,
The undecorated mokko-shaped one is the older of the two. Given the style of the plate and shape and the angle of the kozuka ana (the oval opening) it may be as old as the late Muromachi to Momoyama period (late 16th C). Given the style of raised rim, it would probably be designated as a Katchushi (armor maker's) tsuba, although that is more a convenient term than a literal truth. It's a nicely proportioned and apparently well made guard, although simple. It looks like there is black lacquer on a lot of the surface.

The style of the dragon on the other tsuba is typical for Echizen Kinai work from the mid to late Edo period. It's often seen in larger tsuba, but less common in tanto guards. Given the soft detail and the look of the seppa dai (the central flat oval) it might be cast. I can't tell for sure from the photos.

What does the rest of the mounting with the older guard look like?

Jim



Hi

i made a trade a did get two "Tantos", can anyone tell me something
about the tsubas that were mounted on them, se pics under photos
Tsubas2.jpg , would be nice to now age or something on them

Best Regards

Patrik
